text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with broiled chicken that's right
today we're covering the lost art of
broiling chicken a method that used to
be a lot more popular in fact a smaller
two and a half pound chicken is actually
called a broiler and if done correctly
you're going to be enjoying something
that looks and feels in tastes like it
came off a grill so this is a great plan
B for when you want to grill chicken but
the weather didn't cooperate and you're
stuck inside this is going to work
beautifully and this is how you do it so
first up we're going to need some kind
of pan or dish to broiler chicken in and
for me a baking dish works great for
that and as you can see I actually put
some sliced onion in the bottom not only
is that onion going to subtly sweeten
the chicken but it's also going to add
some moisture into what is an otherwise
dry heat method and then on top of that
I'm going to lay my chicken I got two
halves and one thing you do want to pay
attention to here is to make sure this
chicken is very dry so if there is some
dampness make sure you pat it with a
paper towel before you lay it in here
and then all we need to do here before
it goes under the broiler is season it
up because I'm just doing a simple
techniques demo I'm just going to go
with salt but if you were to use some
other kind of dry rub combination how
would be cool with that in fact I would
encourage it but anyway I'm going to
season that skin-side generously with
kosher salts and I'm going to go ahead
and flip it over and we'll go ahead and
season that other side and we're
actually going to start it under the
broiler this way
which we'll call the bone side I guess
so we will generously salt that side
also and at that point it's ready to go
under the broiler and here's mine
fairly standard gas style broiler heat
coming from the top and I'll talk more
about this on the blog but ideally I
like my chicken to be about seven or
eight inches under the heat we'll go
ahead and grab that chicken put it under
the broiler and I'm gonna let that go
for about seven minutes and I'm going to
take it out it's going to look something
like that
and I will go ahead and flip it over and
then I'm not sure if you have to it I
did reapply some salt to the skin side
it just seemed like it wanted me to do
that so always listen to your chicken
and then we're going to go ahead and put
that back in for another seven minutes
and we're going to kind of repeat that
process letting it go for six or seven
minutes flipping it over letting that
side go for six or seven minutes
flipping it back over etc so a little
bit of a simulation of a rotisserie
method where the chickens natural fat
and juices are kind of basting the other
side
rundown and after seven minutes on that
side that's what we were looking at and
because a broiler is just really an
upside down grill you are going to get
the same kind of caramelization and char
marks as you would on a grill but that's
fine we want that when it comes to
grilling and broiling charring is caring
you've seen the t-shirt so we'll flip
that over and at this point we're about
halfway through the cooking process give
or take you know I don't give exact
times I mean roughly this should take
you about a half hour 35 minutes
something like that but you know the
drill you're going to double-check with
a thermometer so I'm gonna go ahead and
pop that back in for seven minutes and
then ideally we want to finish with the
skin side up so we'll flip it over and
we'll finish it like that so we get a
nice crisp finish and the reason this
method works so nicely is because like
the outdoor grill you're getting a very
intense dry direct heat and if I said it
once I've said it a hundred times half
chickens love dry intense direct heat so
I let that go for about seven minutes
and when mine was done it looked like
this it really should look like
something that came off the backyard
grill and not only will it look like it
hopefully it sounds like it check it out
in fact to be honest that probably
sounds better than what you get off a
backyard grill oh by the way you didn't
hear this for me but save those onions
and when you're done eating your chicken
you can combine that with the bones and
make a couple cups of really nice stock
today we're going to plate that up I'm
going to serve this very simply half a
lemon with some fresh oregano on it and
that side dish is definitely not a
quinoa salad that my wife made me eat I
forget what it actually was but it
wasn't that and then a neat little trick
here when I go to squeeze the lemon
actually smash that oregano into it as I
squeezed and that's going to give that
juice a little touch of that herby
flavor very nice so I squeezed that over
I went ahead and cut in and it was
magnificent so tender so juicy so
flavorful and again it's only with salt
here imagine this with your favorite
spice rub I mean I don't even know what
that is I'm imagining it's going to be
amazing
and we'll do one more a little closer up
and I don't mean to brag but you can
really see in this close-up just how
juicy and succulent that meat is but
anyway like I said I wanted to do a
little refresher course on the beauty of
the broiled chicken oh by the way this
is another 1080p test
and probably the last one that I will
mention eventually they're all going to

otherwise I really hope you give this
